title: How can we write a post on Medium? - Quora

response.answer_text: Three years ago, I decided to start writing (almost) every day on Medium and it was one of the best decision I’ve ever made. My background was in freelance design and I wanted to write a book. After receiving advice from a friend who had been writing for a while, I decided to instead start a Medium publication called The Imperfectionist. What started as one post turned into a posting schedule of 2–3 times each week. Over the years, this turned into a solid body of writing that I could leverage for other opportunities (guest contributing, speaking opportunities, even paid gigs). At this point, I am focused on turning this blog into a platform for my first book about making your own ideas happen. When you start writing on Medium, my advice is to remember the following quote from Ernest Hemingway: “The first draft of anything is shit.” Once you’re ready to get started, publish your first post using this framework for getting started. After using it every day for three years now, I really do believe Medium is the easiest, most accessible site for drafting, editing, publishing, and sharing your writing online. In terms of your blogging topics, I feel like the best subjects for satisfy all three of the following categories: Something you are passionate aboutSomething that you have unique perspective onSomething that is useful for othersPersonally, I created my blog around sharing how to make your own ideas happen because: I am extremely passionate about helping others create their own paths and pursue their own ideasI’ve been freelancing/pursuing my own ideas for my entire professional career (almost a decade)Throughout this time, I’ve met countless individuals who are struggling with common issues (how to position their idea, how to remove yourself as a roadblock, etc.) and they fall into three categories: 1) students, 2) independent creatives, and 3) people who work in corporate settingsAdmittedly, this may take more introspection on your part to find out what satisfies these three areas. Once you do, it will motivate you to blog consistently, which is, by far, the most important thing for growing an audience. Here is the process I’ve used in order to grow an audience on Medium: Write every day for at least 30 minutes and publish 2–3 times a week on The Imperfectionist.Set up a newsletter using MailChimp and Upscribe, a service that allows you to crate embeddable email capture forms. Include a form at the end of each article.I use my weekly newsletter to provide value through tidbits of advice for making ideas happen while also sharing early content from my book (outlines, sections, etc.)Continue building this community for the release of future products and services (an engaged audience is always better when it comes to offering products).Don’t forget: creating and sustaining a high-quality blog is a long-term commitment. Hopefully this helps! Let me know if you have any other questions about Medium or blogging in general. Cheers and good luck!

A complete guide to starting writing your first post on Medium: Writing on Medium is fun. You publish content on Medium for free and can make money without investing a single dollar. According to the Medium earning survey, 5% of the writers on Medium make more than $100 in the month of June 2020. Medium is like YouTube but in this case, you getting paid for getting more views from Medium members.  Before you starting writing on Medium you need to need to know about somethings that might help in the Medium journey. The two most important things on Medium is Curation and Publications. Getting your story curated in a topic means that the Medium algorithm will recommend your story to the Interested readers of that topic. If your story is under the Paywall then Medium algorithm will automatically pick your story for getting read from Curators, which later they decide about the eligibility of getting curated or not.There are some very underrated things on Medium that you should know about like publishing more stories will make you more money and other 5 things 5 Medium Earning Secrets That You Might Don’t Know AboutYou can still make money even if your story didn’t get curated or published in a popular publication, but making $100 a month isn’t possible unless and until you keyword that most Medium members are searching for.Search Engine Optimization (SEO) is also an important factor. As a writer on Medium, this is your responsibility to learn SEO. This complete guide for the medium writer will help you to better understand the SEO Medium SEO: How To Rank Your Medium Articles In Google SearchWhen you submit stories to Publications, some require you to send a draft but you can send sent draft directly if you added as a writer but in some publication, you have to copy your draft link and send them through some form. Now, some publications take a week while others like “ILLUMINATION” takes less than 30 minutes to get your story published.As a writer who makes more than $200 a month from the last three months, with just 6-months of writing on Medium, the thing is that your first draft maybe not that good or you might not getting curated, but one thing to keep in mind is that you have to put your effort and believe in yourself in this whole journey. I know making $200 isn’t a very big deal but still making money from a platform just because of sharing your knowledge or experience is worth trying for. Most writers on Medium think that Medium only promote the work of authors who are publishing from very long or they give favor to certain publications which are completely wrong, in fact, if your story isn’t getting curated or published in a popular publication, you can try these 19 ways to get more views on your Medium stories 19 Ways To Get More People Read Your Medium Stories The Two Ways To Make money from your stories: Medium Partner Program: Medium Partner Program is the official way to make money from Medium. You have to be in the Stripe eligible country in order to get into the Medium Partner Program. The earning is calculated based on Medium member read time, so let say you have to write 1,000 words stories with just a single image then it is calculated as a 4-Minutes read time. Let say a Medium member reading your 4-minutes read story and he just read your story for 2 minutes, so you will be getting paid for that 2-minutes reading time. Is Medium Partner program Worth it?Affiliate marketing: Affiliate marketing is allowed on Medium. You can promote a quality product or service through Medium. Recently I have made a deal of $500 with a company for affiliate marketing through my Medium stories. But, there is something you had to do and that’s to add a disclosure to your Medium stories about the affiliate link. How can we write a post on Medium? Make your Medium account or if you have already, add a picture and add your bio in the Medium profile.Click on your Profile, a drop-down menu will appear.Click on “New Story”Boom, you can now start writing on Medium. Add a Title and start writing your first story on Medium. You can check out my Medium publication Menlo Blogging – Medium and you can follow me on Medium here: Aamir Kamal 🚀🚀🚀 – Medium

I won’t enter in the details of opening an account or menu items. Too much to tell, but you can probably easily sort out that stuff. If you already have an external blog, probably the best thing is to continue publishing your stories there and then import them in Medium. That way, search engines will continue to index the stories on your blog. Else, you just have to hit new story. Main advice: Good title and good featured picture, as you would do on any other blog. Remember that readers will click only because of those. Title is most important, of course, but don’t neglect the picture (and put the credit reference above it).Use all the 5 tags, and in a strategic way. Keep a list of your preferred tags and try to focus your articles on some of them. That way, you will reach a focused audience and you’ll have the opportunity to earn the Best Writer award for one or more of the topics. Include 1–2 tags related with the title (same words is best).Read and comment (appropriately…), a lot. This is fundamental. Else, nobody will see you. Use tags in comments too. Comments count as stories.Don’t be stingy with following interesting authors. Sometimes they follow you back, and this is important at the beginning, to build a minimum number of followers.It’s not necessary to publish daily but it’s a good practice to publish at least twice per week, else you’ll have too few possibilities of being visible.Don’t be discouraged by low stats. Nobody will read your first stories, unless you are already notorious.Once you know the basics, submit to publications. Read those publication, see if they have “submission guidelines” and follow instructions. Usually they ask for drafts (not published stories). If they won’t answer in a couple of days, the story is probably rejected, but sometimes it can take more. It’s up to you to wait or submit to another publications (or publish on your own), and maybe retry in future with a different story. The first time, they have to add you as a writer. After that, you submit stories to publications from the menu.About writing, all the usual advice apply but the two most important for me are: Have your message clear before writing. If it’s not clear for you, the article will be a mess. Readers will notice and it won’t have an impact.Catchy titles are ok but don’t fool your readers. Always deliver what is promised by the title.

just go to Medium dot com, create an account. You don’t need to pay a monthly fee as you get a few free articles per month and your writing account is part of that. If you want to be paid for your writing, join the partner program which is also free. You’ll need to setup a Stripe account (also free) which is the means by which they pay you. From there, just start writing in the platform. Personally I write in Google docs and copy my work onto medium. You can add photos, links, headlines etc. Create a Title for each article with a tagline. Try to make the article title catchy and raise a question in the reader’s mind so that they want to find out more. If you have a blog, you can post the article both on medium and your blog, but make sure to add a canonical link in Medium so that Google doesn’t penalise you for the double-up. If your writing is good enough, you might get curated which will put your article on the homepage, so you’ll get more views. It takes time to get success but keep going with publishing and you’ll get there. There’s a really good interview with a successful writer on youtube. Its on the digital nomad TV channel. I found it very inspiring. The writer is making over 10k per month on medium.

Sign up, click the story and start writing. Simple as that. The rest will follow. Write about arenas you care about, whether it be: PoliticsPersonal GrowthArtful storiesEconomicsStartupsInnovationArtTips/AdviceUse it even as a brain dump of how you are feeling that day. Write often and try to publish several times a week. Use the backlinks and the tags strategically. Once you write enough the tags that you select in the article right before you publish will become a strategic source as to how any publication on Medium (social media) will find you. Once they find you and add you as a writer, you will notice a much bigger platform a bigger audience to reach and soon it, could start working for you. Write away!

Medium – a place to read and write big ideas and important stories is an online publishing platform developed by Evan Williams, and launched in August 2012. It is owned by A Medium Corporation. The platform is an example of social journalism, having a hybrid collection of amateur and professional people and publications, or exclusive blogs or publishers on Medium, and is regularly regarded as a blog host.  Medium is a web 2.0 platform which provides a space to every user on the platform to post and interact. While you can start with the free plan. You can start your journey by clicking at the Get started button on the platform.  You can login directly via your Google or Facebook account and start publishing within a matter of seconds by choosing the ‘New Story’ from the top right menu.  So, I wish you happy blogging! :D

Why not take a look at How to Use Medium: A Beginner's Guide to Writing, Publishing & Promoting on the Platform as you wait for answers here. While it’s aimed at marketers, 90 percent of the advice is great for an aspiring writer such as yourself. After all, to write for Medium you just need an account. To get read on Medium, that’s another matter altogether. While you’re at it, read other people’s writing on Medium. It’s a terrific experience to look for the articles that you might have written yourself, and then to use your powers of observation to see what you can learn about why some got a better reception than others. Perhaps by then, other Quorans will have shared their wisdom here.
I have only one. Don’t plagiarize someone else’s writing pieces that you copied word for word from Quora and claimed as your own. (Yes, that happened to me.)

Research their website. Really research. Step one would be to set up a profile. There are guidelines for that on their website. After that, write and write and write. Publish direct or see if an online publication on Medium will publish your work. Pay super careful attention to the tags which you can utilize. Read about Medium Membership. It really is too much to condense here. But, I repeat myself, go to Medium – a place to read and write big ideas and important stories. And research. Good luck. It’s a lot of fun and you will meet incredible fellow writers.

Very simple. Log in with your Twitter credentials, click on New Story in the top right corner of the home page and start writing! The beauty of Medium is that you need to do very minimal formatting to make your post look amazing. If you need to, you can share your draft with others before you publish it, get feedback, make changes and then hit publish.   I find Medium much easier to write in than even my WordPress site. If you're undecided about what to write and the structure of your post (lists vs. essays for instance), start reading some posts and following collections on Medium. Good luck!

I would say that the basics stay the same, ie, rules of the game for writing, making a contribution over a collaborative platform are more or less like what expert writers advise over and over. I would try to summarize those points for you precisely and clearly: Start with the topics/areas you have good knowledge ofTry to solve people's problems with what you knowKeep it as simple as possible and clearNon-saturated topics are your best buddy to help others and gain tractionKeep your voice and don't hesitate to share new ideasBe available for further assistance, clarification, etc.I hope it helps.
